text: I am trying to play an audio cd, however, ubuntu wont even recognize I have a cd in the cdrom.  How do I fix this?
It doesn't even show a cdrom...
just shows: desktop, filesystem
I can press the button on the cd rom to eject the cd...and I put it back in and still nothing..
- run cdeject from the console
- a terminal
- command prompt in Windows language
- so type in sudo apt-get install cdtool
- with Linux you'll be using terminals and typing commands a lot more than you did in Windows - there are a lot of reasons for the difference which I won't bore you with at the moment :P
- I'm unfamilar with guild wars so you'll have to walk me through how you played it on Windows
- so you need to run it from CDZ
- sorry, I meant to type CD?
- are you trying to run guild wars from a CD or from the Internet?
- back in your console, type 'sudo apt-get install wine'
- so let's see if I can have you up and running in 15 minutes :P
- right, okay... just a sec
- CD? are you having troubles with the CD again?
- and lemmie know when you have Wine installed
- well if you invested 3 hours already into setting it up you must have SOME patience...
- the popular saying about Linux and Windows is that Linux is impossible to set up but easy to maintain whereas Windows is easy to set up but impossible to maintain
- and the eggheads over in development are working on fixing the former issue
- well let's see if I can get guildwars working first...
- then we'll deal with the cd issue
- now do you have guild wars on CD or do you download it?
- okay, pop the CD in and see what happens
- okay, that's probably because Linux tends not always to support autoruns for Windows... no matter.  See if you can open a file explorer (Windows Explorer in Windows world)
- are you able to find your CD?
I put the Guild Wars CD into the CD-ROM and Ubuntu doesn't even say the CD is in the CD-ROM.
- not at the moment
- look at the top menu and click on 'Places'
- open your terminal up again
- in the prompt, type mount... a bunch of things should pop up
- just checking on that... okay, now type 'sudo mount /dev/cd0 /mnt/'
- make sure there's a space between cd0/ and /mnt/
- my mistake, /dev/cd0 should have been /dev/cdrom
- does clicking on it not work?
- excellent.  Now type 'cd /mnt'
- okay, so that probably means Ubuntu has found the CD
- so were you able to 'cd /mnt/'?
- sweet.  Type 'ls' I want to know what the setup executable is
- type 'wine setup.exe'
- yessir.  The setup program should run like it was in Windows
- what did it complain about?
- how big is the dump?
- stand by... can you file transfer it over?
- not entirely sure :S
- that's not my specialty
- stand by... posting a fix
- pick up a script from http://rhodes.awardspace.info/winebuild.sh
- and run it :D
- as in save it to your desktop and click on the icon?
- did you save it to your desktop or your home folder?
- in console type 'sh ~/Destop/winebuild.sh'
- my bad, I misspelt 'Desktop'
- y to everything
- it looks like it will take a few minutes to straighten itself out
- my pleasure.  Linux has it's quirks but I believe in it far more than Windows.  The good news from all of this is that once you get it running, you'll never have to fix it
How come you can get this far but the other people who helped me couldn't?
- probably not :P  Seriously, my job is tech support so my survival relies entirely upon ingenuity and patience :P
- http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=77LBQxa5o5w
- just so you know that success IS possible
- right, there's a fix for that too 'sudo apt-get install flashplayer-nonfree'
- well I don't want to spoil it but it looks like it works perfectly :D
- you're on a highspeed Internet connection, right?
- sadly, yes.. but I'm trying to convert my clients to Linux :D
- no, I work for myself and have nothing for contempt for Microsoft
- how are we looking?
- what is it downloading?
- sounds good
- ubuntu has some very addictive free games
- I've always been a tetris addict myself
- make sure you spell my name correctly ;)
ah

- like you won't believe

familiarise yourself with Synaptic... it gets you everything you could ever need

Synaptic is the easiest way to install things without messing about with apt-gets
but jetscreamer's way works too
try CTRL + ALT + Backspace.  It restarts the windowing system (and eliminates most problems) without having to restart the program

you can always google or go to UbuntuForums.org to find out how to make CTRL+ALT+Delete work

and there's no spit-out in the console?
okay, in that case, run the command but add ' > ~/Dump.txt' to the end of the command
yep, this is linux, most things are done at the command because it's easier than saying 'now click on Start-> All Programs...'
just keep pressing up in the console until you find it
cuz I'm too lazy to copy and paste it :P
christopher@christopher-desktop:~$ wine ~/.wine/drive_c/Program\ Files/Guild\ Wars/Gw.exe > ~/Dump.txt
yes
all that does is save the dump to a file so you can collect it and post it to http://paste.ubuntu-nl.org/30878/

you can, but not necessarily.  Are you using a 64-bit processor?

AMD Athlon 64 x2 Dual Core Processor 4000+

so get another cup of coffee

new file: http://rhodes.awardspace.info/winebuild64.sh save it to your hard drive
okay
We have to do some of this work again... but I hope it'll be faster.  Once you have it run it from the console: 'sh ~/Desktop/winebuild64.sh'

hmmm... the possible causes for error have opened up a little bit...
that's the thing.  If you have a 64-bit computer you should be using a 64-bit version of Ubuntu
I don't know whether using a 32-bit operating system on a 64-bit processor is the reason for your problem.  It could be, it could be something else

the emulator reads a file like Word reads documents

you're welcome but good intentions doesn't get you slaying orcs

most likely from the command line.  Unfortunately, things like emulators don't always install shortcuts.  Open a prompt and type 'nestra'
then it's usually 'nestra <path to whatever your NES rom is called>'

oh what is the command for flash player?
'sudo apt-get install flashplayer-nonfree'
do as it says :D
to navigate directories you use 'cd <directory>'
The Guild Wars problem is likely because you need a 64-bit edition of Ubuntu, sadly

well it's not quite that simple.  You're looking at reinstalling your operating system

alternatively, if you have 3 weeks to kill you can order a copy from Canonical and they'll ship it to you for free
http://www.ubuntu.com/getubuntu/download you want the 64bit AMD version

okay, save that file to your desktop, right click it and say something to the effect of 'extract here'

so you have a directory called C on your desktop?
so the directory is actually called ~/Desktop/C/
it's the same idea in Windows where Desktop is actually C:\My Documents\bunch of rubbish\Desktop
that also works :D
this is why people should have a trained professional helping them install Linux :D
